botanical_details.genus: Streptocarpus can be annuals, perennials or subshrubs, with usually wrinkled, lance-shaped to rounded leaves and clusters of tubular to trumpet-shaped flowers with 5 spreading lobes, often borne throughout the year

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow as a houseplant in loamless potting compost on an east or west-facing windowsill, or grow in a temperate or warm greenhouse in bright filtered light with shade from hot sun. Water sparingly as compost dries in winter and in the growing season water freely allowing compost to dry out between waterings; feed fortnightly with a high-potassium fertiliser. See Streptocarpus cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by either division of clumps or by leaf cuttings in spring or summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead regularly and removes damaged leaves
how_to_grow.pests: May be attacked by glasshouse leafhoppers, mealybugs, thrips, vine weevil and tarsonemid mite
how_to_grow.diseases: Overwatering may cause rotting at base of the plant
